message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest rotator cuff tendinopathy, as there is pain during active abduction and passive internal rotation. Adhesive capsulitis would have restricted range of motion, while biceps tendinopathy and glenohumeral osteoarthritis typically present with pain in different locations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, particularly pain on active abduction and passive internal rotation, are indicative of rotator cuff tendinopathy. Adhesive capsulitis would have limited range of motion and is usually a more gradual onset. Biceps tendinopathy and glenohumeral osteoarthritis would have different patterns of pain and limited range of motion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest rotator cuff tendinopathy, which is characterized by pain in the shoulder when reaching overhead or lifting the arm, as well as pain with internal rotation. Adhesive capsulitis would typically present with decreased range of motion and pain at all ranges, while biceps tendinopathy and glenohumeral osteoarthritis would typically present with pain or weakness during resisted elbow flexion or abduction, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with shoulder pain that is worse when reaching overhead and is reproduced on active abduction of the right arm and passively internally rotating and then lifting the shoulder. This suggests rotator cuff tendinopathy, which can occur due to overuse or injury. Adhesive capsulitis can also cause shoulder pain and limited range of motion, but active and passive range of motion are full in this case. Biceps tendinopathy and glenohumeral osteoarthritis may also cause shoulder pain, but the specific movements that reproduce the pain and tenderness on palpation are not typically associated with these conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are suggestive of rotator cuff tendinopathy, which involves pain when reaching overhead and during passive internal rotation. Adhesive capsulitis involves more limited range of motion and glenohumeral osteoarthritis involves pain throughout the joint, not just in the lateral shoulder. Biceps tendinopathy would involve pain in the anterior shoulder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of pain with overhead activities and passive internal rotation suggest rotator cuff tendinopathy. Adhesive capsulitis would have limited passive and active range of motion. Biceps tendinopathy would have pain with resisted elbow flexion. Glenohumeral osteoarthritis would have joint pain and stiffness that is worse with activity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest rotator cuff tendinopathy, which is characterized by pain in the shoulder when reaching overhead and on internal rotation. The other options have different clinical features: Adhesive capsulitis involves decreased range of motion and pain in multiple directions, biceps tendinopathy involves pain in the front of the shoulder, and glenohumeral osteoarthritis involves pain with movement and can have a bony crepitus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including pain on active abduction and passive internal rotation, suggest rotator cuff tendinopathy. Adhesive capsulitis would have limited passive and active range of motion. Biceps tendinopathy would have pain with resisted elbow flexion. Glenohumeral osteoarthritis would have pain with multiple activities and limited range of motion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest rotator cuff tendinopathy. Adhesive capsulitis usually presents with a significant decrease in both active and passive range of motion, while glenohumeral osteoarthritis usually presents with pain during active and passive motion in multiple planes, as well as joint crepitus. Biceps tendinopathy usually presents with pain in the bicipital groove that is exacerbated with supination and passive shoulder flexion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially pain with active abduction above 90 degrees and internal rotation, suggest the most likely diagnosis is rotator cuff tendinopathy. Adhesive capsulitis would likely have limited passive range of motion as well, while biceps tendinopathy and glenohumeral osteoarthritis typically do not present with pain reproduced in those specific maneuvers.
